docs.lead_paragraph: Postmasters 459 West 19th Street, Chelsea Through March 15 Like an after-school special from hell, Sue de Beer's fragmented video ''Hans und Grete'' addresses suicide, satanism, joyless sex, narcissism, teen violence, teen pregnancy, depression and the German Baader-Meinhoff terrorist gang (don't ask).

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, women have been asking, ''When?'' They got their answer this week when a small New Jersey pharmaceutical company announced that it was shipping out new supplies of the Today Sponge, a popular over-the-counter method of birth-control that was discontinued in 1994.

headline.main: Many Women Gleeful at Old Friend's Encore

docs.abstract: Today Sponge, once popular over-the-counter method of birth control, is returning to market after being out of production since 1994; sponge is being produced by Allendale Pharmaceuticals in New Jersey, which expects to have it in US stores by fall, pending Food and Drug Administration approval; meanwhile, Allendale is shipping to Canada, where Web site distributing device has been deluged with requests; chronology; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For years, women have been asking, ''When?''    They got their answer this week when a small New Jersey pharmaceutical company announced that it was shipping out new supplies of the Today Sponge, a popular over-the-counter method of birth-control...

docs.lead_paragraph: Mothers Work, the world's largest retailer of maternity clothes, lowered its second-quarter earnings and sales forecasts yesterday, saying that women were buying more discounted clothing and fewer full-price items. The shares fell 20 percent. Profit is expected to be 15 cents a share on sales of $111 million for the quarter ending March 31, below its previous forecast of 22 to 27 cents on sales of $114 million, Mothers Work said. Severe weather, including a blizzard over the Washington's Birthday weekend, led customers to buy fewer clothes, Mothers Work said. Sales at stores open at least a year fell 5 percent last month. Stock in Mothers Work fell $5.72, to $22.48 a share.

headline.main: MOTHERS WORK LOWERS SALES AND EARNINGS FORECASTS

docs.abstract: Mothers Work Lowers Sales and Earnings Forecast

docs.lead_paragraph: Heavy consumption of coffee during pregnancy appears to be associated with a higher risk of stillbirth, researchers have found. The researchers, from Aarhus University in Denmark, said the caffeine in coffee was presumably responsible for the increased risk. Exactly how caffeine affects the fetus is unclear, they said, noting that the increase in stillbirths may also be partly explained by other risky behaviors.

headline.main: When Coffee Puts Fetus at Risk

docs.abstract: Researchers find that heavy consumption of coffee during pregnancy appears to be associated with higher risk of stillbirth; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than four years after a Buffalo-area doctor was shot to death through his kitchen window, jury selection is to begin today in the trial of the abortion opponent accused in the killing. The shooting of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian received international attention, both for its calculated nature and for the trans-Atlantic manhunt that ensued. Investigators tracked the defendant, James C. Kopp, who was linked to violent anti-abortion groups, to Ireland but then lost his trail. They finally picked him up in March 2001 in France.

headline.main: Defense Intends to Make Trial of Doctor's Killer a Forum on Abortion

docs.abstract: Jury selection begins in trial of James Kopp, abortion foe who is accused in 1998 killing of Dr Barnett A Slepian in Amherst, NY; shooting received international attention both for its calculated nature and for manhunt that ensued until Kopp was tracked down in France; Kopp admits killing Slepian, but says he intended only to injure him to prevent him from performing abortions; defense will plead justifiable homicide, as Kopp's lawyers intend to turn trial into forum on abortion; Kopp faces similar charges in Canada; photo (M)
docs.snippet: More than four years after a Buffalo-area doctor was shot to death through his kitchen window, jury selection is to begin today in the trial of the abortion opponent accused in the killing.    The shooting of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian received...

docs.lead_paragraph: A MARRIAGE rescue plan: Get a tan. Hire a personal trainer. Have liposuction. Enlarge breasts. She might not have jotted down a list like that, but the Houston dentist Clara Harris testified last month that she had started working on all four goals to save her 10-year marriage. The rescue campaign became irrelevant, of course. Dr. Harris was found guilty of murdering her husband, who was having an affair, by repeatedly running him over with her Mercedes in a hotel parking lot.

headline.main: A Makeover Can Be More Than Skin Deep

docs.abstract: Ellyn Spragins column notes women and men who have cosmetic surgery report they feel better about themselves and that people around them seem to like them better; notes relationships are often strained before cosmetic procedures by prospect of physical transformation; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Winemakers may put health claims on their bottles, the government decided yesterday, but only if they are either highly detailed, with numerous qualifications that emphasize facts the wine industry might not like to have publicized, or if they simply tell consumers where to find health-related information. The rules appear to have trod a middle ground between opponents of alcohol, who were outraged that winemakers might be able to make health claims that would encourage people to drink, and those who argued that winemakers had a First Amendment right to make any statements they wanted about the health benefits of their products, so long as they were accurate.

headline.main: U.S. to Allow Wine Labels That List Health Claims

docs.abstract: Treasury Department rules that winemakers may put health claims on labels but only if they are highly detailed, including qualifications that industry may not wish publicized, or if they simply tell consumers where to find health-related information; aim is balance between opponents of alcohol and winemakers' rights to make accurate claims; photo (M)
